docs.lead_paragraph: As state legislative sessions open across the country this week, Republican governors and lawmakers in many states are mounting major campaigns to control medical malpractice insurance premiums by limiting civil litigation. In Georgia, Missouri, Washington and more than a dozen other states, Republican legislators have made malpractice premiums a priority this year, groups that track such legislation said. In Kentucky, Maryland and Mississippi, Republican governors have already waded into the fray.

headline.main: A Push in States to Curb Malpractice Costs

docs.abstract: Republican governors and lawmakers in many states are mounting campaigns to control medical malpractice insurance premiums by limiting civil litigation; impending battles have, in some states, been wrapped in broader cloak of 'tort reform,' intended to restrict civil liability of many types of businesses; soaring malpractice premiums are driving force for campaign, in part because compelling stories about doctors and patients put human face on larger issue; chart shows efforts and progress on issue in nine states; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Republicans are mounting campaigns to control medical malpractice insurance premiums by limiting civil litigation.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: America, the richest country, is falling further behind others in infant mortality. Limiting access to health care, rather than medical sophistication, accounts for the problem.

headline.main: Why Are Infants at Risk in America?

docs.abstract: Dr Joe Brooks letter on Nicholas D Kristof's Jan 12 column says US infant mortality rate would improve if there were single-payer national health care system
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    America, the richest country, is falling further behind others in infant mortality. Limiting access to health care, rather than medical sophistication, accounts for the problem.

docs.lead_paragraph: General Motors said Thursday that its earnings would fall this year because of rising health care costs and slowing profits at its financing division. ''We obviously are pushing hard in '05 but we're not pleased,'' said John Devine, G.M.'s chief financial officer, at an annual meeting with financial analysts. ''We expect to get back on track in '06 and '07,'' he added.

headline.main: G.M. Forecasts a Decline in Its Earnings for 2005

docs.abstract: General Motors says earnings will fall this year because of rising health care costs and slowing profits at its financing division; chief financial officer John Devine says expects to get back on track in 2006 and 2007; reaffirms its previous forecast that 2004 earnings will be between $6 to $6.50 per share when it reports its fourth-quarter results next week; predicts that earnings for 2005 will fall to range of $4 to $5 per share (M)
docs.snippet: General Motors said Thursday that its earnings would fall this year because of a projected $1 billion rise in health care costs and slowing profits at its financing division.

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE freezing day last month, Dr. Sebastiano Santostefano, a psychoanalyst renowned for his work with traumatized children, strolled through the garden outside the Institute for Child and Adolescent Development, telling the story of ''Ernest,'' a pseudonym for a 4-year-old boy who was so withdrawn and unable to relate to others that his pediatrician suspected he was autistic. ''This is the 'cave' where Ernest and I sat for weeks,'' Dr. Santostefano said, touching the satiny needles of a yew that leans its branches over the slope of a hill. They sat on a flat rock under those branches, mostly in silence, until one day Ernest started a game.

headline.main: The Doctor Is Out (And So Are the Patients)

docs.abstract: Psychoanalyst Dr Sebastiano Santostefano and wife Susan, also therapist, treat traumatized children in homey setting of house and garden in Wellesley, Mass; Santostefano, who formerly directed program at McLean Hospital in Belmont, founded Institute for Child and Adolescent Development in belief that real progress requires more time than insurance restrictions allow; interview; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Dr. Sebastiano Santostefano, a psychoanalyst renowned for his work with children, argues that his garden has played a crucial role in their treatment and growth.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: INSTITUTE FOR CHILD AND ADOLESCENT DEVELOPMENT

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I read with dismay ''A Town in Westchester Ends Health Benefits for Domestic Partners'' (news article, Jan. 6). I am an eight-year resident and property owner in Eastchester, N.Y. My husband, two sons and I live in a neighborhood and community that we very much appreciate. Today, however, I am embarrassed to be connected with the town. To couch this ending of benefits in terms of economics is at best disingenuous. Considering the size of our town budget and the number of employees who are likely to claim these benefits, the savings are not material. This ultimately is an issue driven by the biases of a segment of our community against those who are gay or lesbian. It is a step backward in time and a gesture of disrespect regarding the civil rights of gays and lesbians who work or live here.
docs.abstract: Letter from Mary Messner Martin, resident of Eastchester, NY, says she is embarrassed to be connected with town after its move to end health benefits for domestic partners of town employees (Jan 6 article)
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    I read with dismay ''A Town in Westchester Ends Health Benefits for Domestic Partners'' (news article, Jan. 6). I am an eight-year resident and property owner in Eastchester, N.Y. My husband, two sons and I live in a neighborhood...

docs.lead_paragraph: McKesson, the nation's largest drug distributor, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $960 million to settle a class-action lawsuit based on accounting fraud at HBOC, a health care software company that it bought in 1999. The settlement, which will be divided among New York State pension funds and thousands of other plaintiffs, was one of the largest in history on a list led by $3.2 billion in a class-action suit against the Cendant Corporation and more than $2.6 billion in the WorldCom case, including payments by WorldCom directors.

headline.main: McKesson Agrees to Settle An Accounting Fraud Suit

docs.abstract: McKesson agrees to pay $960 million to settle class-action lawsuit based on accounting fraud at HBOC, health care software company that it bought in 1999; settlement, will be divided among New York State pension funds and thousands of other plaintiffs; settlement ends suit filed after McKesson shareholders lost $8.6 billion in one day, April 28, 1999, nearly half value of their holdings; stock plunged after McKesson said HBOC had improperly booked sales and that it would restate earnings and revenues (M)
docs.snippet: McKesson, the nation's largest drug distributor, agreed to pay $960 million to settle a lawsuit based on accounting fraud at HBOC, a health care software company.

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-18 Congress Scraps Bid To Limit Interrogation At the urging of the White House, Congressional leaders scrapped a legislative measure that would have imposed new restrictions on the use of extreme interrogation measures by American intelligence officers, Congressional officials say. A1 Lawyers for Specialist Charles A. Graner Jr., who is accused of being the ringleader of the Abu Ghraib prison abuse scandal, began presenting their case in his court-martial, arguing consistently that he believed he was acting under legal orders. A18 Chirac Welcomes Iraqi Leader President Jacques Chirac took an important symbolic step toward repairing France's tattered relationship with Iraq, welcoming his Iraqi counterpart for a four-day official visit to France. A16 Indonesia to Expel Troops Indonesia, sensitive to the impression that it was relying too heavily on outside military forces and wanting to assert control over the relief operation, announced that all foreign troops assisting in the relief operation must leave in three months. A18 The gusher of donations in the past few weeks has overwhelmed some charities and the money -- welcome as it is -- has placed a heavy weight on its stewards. A10 New studies show that shock waves from the earthquake ricocheted around the globe for hours and remained so strong that they lifted the earth's surface nearly an inch. A10 Hong Kong Leader Apologizes Facing broad public dissatisfaction and renewed speculation over whether he might step down, Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's leader, made several apologies for his governance but promised to remain in office. A11 Violence Flares Again in Gaza After a brief calm surrounding the Palestinian election, an Israeli man was killed in the Gaza Strip, and Israeli soldiers tracked down and killed four armed Palestinians. A3 NATIONAL A20-32 Federal Judges Regain Discretion in Sentencing The Supreme Court transformed federal criminal sentencing by restoring to judges much of the discretion that Congress took away 21 years ago when it put guidelines in place and told judges to follow. A1 Ruling on Detention of Cubans The Supreme Court ruled that federal law prohibits the open-ended detention of Cubans who entered the United States during the Mariel boatlift in 1980 and who, despite crimes later committed in the United States, cannot be deported. A20 More Fruits and Vegetables The federal government issued new dietary guidelines for Americans, which now emphasize weight loss instead of healthy eating and cardiovascular health. A1 A Shaky Inauguration The swearing-in ceremony for Christine Gregoire, the new Democratic governor of Washington, had all the ritualistic touches, but Republicans continue to question Ms. Gregoire's hold on the office. A20 Revisiting a Taliban Case Newly disclosed documents in the case of John Walker Lindh appear to conflict with assertions Michael Chertoff, now the nominee for homeland security secretary, made to Congress in 2003 about the case. A22 Teamsters Aide Suspended A union oversight board said that a top assistant to the Teamsters president, James P. Hoffa, would be suspended for 60 days and had repaid $69,500, after investigators accused him of embezzlement. A23 Bush Seeks More School Tests President Bush called for a rigorous high school testing program in math and reading that would be a major initiative of his second term. A26 Death of a Whale The endangered North Atlantic right whale grew more scarce when a pregnant female was found dead off Nantucket Island. A32 NEW YORK/REGION B1-10 City Beating Recession, Without Wall Street's Help For the first time in 40 years, New York City is wrestling its way out of a protracted recession without its traditional economic engine -- Wall Street employers -- leading the way. A1 More Nazi-Era Depositors Officials overseeing the settlement of a suit over the conduct of Swiss banks during the Holocaust plan to publish a list of newly released names of depositors that is likely to produce new leads connecting people with bank accounts lost in the Nazi chaos. B1 Arrest in 1983 Homicide A former resident of Plainfield, N.J., was arraigned on a murder charge stemming from a shooting more than 21 years ago, when a man was gunned down on a Plainfield street corner during a bungled drug deal. B1 New Drug Law Takes Effect As a new law meant to ease the effects of New York's strict drug laws goes into full effect today, prosecutors, defense lawyers, prisoners and their families are still struggling to figure out how it will work. B3 Neediest Cases B6 HOUSE & HOME F1-12 CIRCUITS G1-8 OBITUARIES A33 ARTS E1-14 SPORTSTHURSDAY D1-8 Steroids Agreement Reached Major League Baseball officials and the Players Association will announce an agreement on a new steroids testing program, one official from each side said. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-18 U.S. Trade Deficit Soars The United States trade deficit soared to $60.3 billion in November, the Commerce Department reported. The figure breaks all previous monthly records and confounds predictions that the deficit would diminish with the weakening of the dollar and the decline in the price of oil. C2 Army Officers Disciplined Eleven Army officers at Fort Benning, Ga., have been disciplined for allowing life insurance agents to give improper classroom sales pitches to hundreds of trainees at the base last spring, in violation of military rules, according to the base legal office. C4 Business Digest C1 EDITORIAL A30-31 Editorials: Bulletin -- no W.M.D. found; the tsunami and child trafficking; Bloomberg from the block; Apple tries to break out. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman, Maureen Dowd. Bridge E9 TV Listings E13 Crossword E8 Weather A28

docs.lead_paragraph: Ten major pharmaceutical companies said on Tuesday that they were joining in a new program to cut 25 percent to 40 percent from the retail prices of prescription drugs sold to uninsured people of modest means younger than 65. The drug makers, like many Democrats in Congress, painted a grim picture of life without health insurance, saying that millions of Americans went without life-saving drugs because they lacked coverage.

headline.main: Companies Set Program to Cut Prices of 275 Prescription Drugs

docs.abstract: Ten major pharmaceutical companies join in new program to cut 25 percent to 40 percent from retail prices of prescription drugs sold to uninsured people of modest means younger than 65; people who enroll in new program will receive plastic cards that can be used to obtain savings on 275 drugs at local drugstores; federal government has no role in program (M)
docs.snippet: Ten pharmaceutical companies said they were joining a program to cut the prices of prescription drugs for the uninsured.

docs.lead_paragraph: Here's a wrenching fact: If the U.S. had an infant mortality rate as good as Cuba's, we would save an additional 2,212 American babies a year. Yes, Cuba's. Babies are less likely to survive in America, with a health care system that we think is the best in the world, than in impoverished and autocratic Cuba. According to the latest C.I.A. World Factbook, Cuba is one of 41 countries that have better infant mortality rates than the United States.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column deplores infant mortality rates in United States, which is higher than rate for Cuba, China and 39 other countries; says that even more troubling, infant mortality rate in United States has worsened recently (M)
docs.snippet: The average baby is less likely to survive in the U.S. than in Havana.
